In 1880 Sir Francis Galton collected [**data**]{style="color: #005ABB"} on the length of sweet peas.

<br/> <br/> <br/>

Together with Karl Pearson a mathematical [**model**]{style="color: #EF8200"} (algorithm) was created to predict the length of their offspring by the length of the parent.
:::
:::

::: {.notes}
Galton Conclusion: Prediction requires (quality) Data and Algorithm

-   simple linear Model 1 parameter
-   supervised learning (in & output are known, training & test set)
-   low data quality (outliers) may ruin the model: so cleaning or more data
:::

::: {.notes}
decision trees Conclusion: data Quality of the labelled data
- **Decision Trees:** are graphical models that make decisions or predictions based on a series of rules or conditions. They are often used for classification or regression tasks and provide interpretable and understandable models
- automated selection of branches (depth), indicators (width) and order
- supervised model based on a training set of labelled data
- selflearning on the depth, width of given parameters in train set
:::

# Reinforcement Learning {background-color="#F9BD8B" background-image="" background-size="cover"}

::: {.notes}

Reinforcement Learning: In reinforcement learning, an AI agent learns to make decisions by interacting with an environment and receiving feedback in the form of rewards or punishments. The agent learns through trial and error to maximize its cumulative rewards.
